Posts.Content:
Thank you Bev as always solid, empathetic and valuable advice and support!
They took three additional spot views and then did the ultrasound. The radiologist came and spoke with me on the results. He said the spot they were looking at was really really really tiny and just below the skin. It is not even something I could feel. Even a couple of the mammo shots had difficulty finding it. But the ultrasound tech found it without problems. In his opinion it appears to be benign and wants me to do the follow up in 6 months. I asked him if there was any concerns given my family history and he said the concerns are valid, but he did not believe this particular item warranted biopsy. The area in question may also be fatty tissue.
I was satisfied with the results and I do intend on getting my written results. Sound about
 right?
Sue 
Hypothyroid, Chronic Pain associated with Abdominal Adhesions(ARD)with Nerve Damage, Multiple Herniated Disks in Cervical Spine, Anxiety, High Cholesterol, GERD, Diverticulosis, Carpul Tunnel, Abnormal EKG(past mild heart attack?). Surgeries: Hysterectomy, Gallbladder Removed, Bladder Sling, Sinus. On Dilaudid, Flexiril, Xanax, Trazodone, Synthroid, Anatara and Simvastatin
Posts.Title: I'm back... Another year another follow up needed

Posts.Content:
Hi Bev and All.
Last years mammo resulted in the need for additional spot views for some microcalcifications. Did the spot view and was given the wait and see on them that I could go back to yearly screenings. I was ok with that. Now this year something different. The dr's nurse called Thursday evening to say that I needed to go for an ultrasound, but not to freak out it is most likely something benign. So I scheduled with the breast care center for my US and they asked me for a diagnosis??? I felt stupid and could only say dense breasts. My gut feeling spoke very loud to me that night. No spot view, I had no clear understanding of what exactly they were wanting a second look at. I called the breast care center and ask for clarification. GOOD thing. The radiologist wanted a spot view AND an ultrasound. The report indicates a lymph node or module needs further evaluation. While it may be benign they need to make sure because I do have dense breasts. I told the lady that the nurse made no mention of the spot view so they were going to have to re-do the order. The lady made it a point to say the spot view was required and she would contact my dr office for the change. She called me back to make sure I knew to come early for the spot view and that they were able to fit it in before my US.
While I have anxiety, I am not freaking out like last year. Is it bad that I told my hubby that I did not need him to take off for this. He did so last year as I was told the radiologist would speak with us afterward, and all that took place was the tech ran out of the room while I put my shirt on, came back and said I could go they would watch it and to schedule a 6 month f/u. Here is my thought, IF further evaluation is needed it will be a biopsy and of course he will need to be there. 
Question, IF a biopsy is needed I am NOT up for needle anything. With my mother passing away (at my age now) I don't want anything left in that "could" turn later. I have already had a lumpectomy through my general surgeon a few years ago (fatty necrosis tissue). IF this needs biopsy do I stick with my general surgeon at this point or should I consider an oncologist type of surgeon given my history?
Posts.Title: I'm back... Another year another follow up needed

Posts.Content: Went for my normal screening mammo last week, well they are calling me back.  According to my doctor the radiologist says there are two areas of calcification that need further evaluation.  He said while ordinarily these tend to be benign, these two calcifications were not there on my previous exam.  I am trying to not obsess over this and while I need to go for more detailed views, the radiologist did not feel a ultrasound was necessary.  So I go back next Wednesday.  Then it will probably be another few days for those results.
Posts.Title: Called Back for a Diagnostic Mammo

Posts.Content:
Thank you Bev. I am thankful they were able to get me in next week. So I am trying to keep my thoughts busy with work and Christmas shopping. It's the quiet time I have a hard time with. That when the what if's start cropping up.
Thanks for letting me get out some of my anxiety.
Sue
Posts.Title: Called Back for a Diagnostic Mammo

Posts.Content:
I know they are the worst.  The last time I went through this was a little rushed and backwards.  I have read a few posts about
 call backs, so I am wondering.  When you go in and they do the spot views, do they normally let you know before you leave what the results are?  I am having mine done at my local hospital in their breast care center.
Posts.Title: Called Back for a Diagnostic Mammo

Posts.Content:
I went through this very tough decision a few years ago. The surgeon basically put it to me this way..... Most of his patients that opt to wait versus just proceeding with the excisional biopsy, are back in his office within 30 days ready to go. Because they find themselves obsessing with checking the spot so often, they end up getting sore or bruised. I went with the excisional biopsy, which was his recommendation.
That way I could move forward, instead of worrying about
 what it was. I went in and was home in a few hours. Knock on wood, the diagnosis was B9.
Good Luck.
Sue
Posts.Title: Excisional Breast Biopsy

Posts.Content: Nannonanno, I too am worried, but am very thankful for Bev, Kat, and Gail who to take time to help those of us travel through this very confusing road.
Posts.Title: Called Back for a Diagnostic Mammo

Posts.Content: Thank you Kat.  Actually your kind words and experience did ease my tensions enough where I could go out last night and enjoy a dinner out with friends and escape my thoughts for awhile.
Posts.Title: Called Back for a Diagnostic Mammo

Posts.Content:
Yaaaa Bev 16 years. I will pray for your health and continued well being. It has been suggested that I go for the genetic testing, but I have held off. Without laws in place to prevent insurance companies from denying coverage, I have to wait until that sticks. Especially after what I was exposed to last year when our company was interviewing health insurance companies. One of the companies would only provide coverage to us if they could choose who they cover. This is the honest truth. Maybe some day, but for now I can't risk loosing insurance coverage. That is the reality of where we are at this point.
I did some reviewing of my last round of mammo results Birads 2, there are already some calcifications they are watching, and have been since 2004. Maybe the new calcifications appear different as I have not had to have a follow up mammo until now. I will have to wait for Wednesday......
Time will tell.... Susie
Sue
Posts.Title: Called Back for a Diagnostic Mammo

Posts.Content:
Besides my hubby you angels are the first to know.....
!  
 They took 3 views the first time.  Then one more angle, and the whole hour and a half resulted in the radiologist diagnosis of benign appearing calcifications, and I should have a follow up mammo in 6 months.
Posts.Title: Called Back for a Diagnostic Mammo

Posts.Content:
I have to go with the wait for now. I will trust the radiologist, she was a lady. I will also be asking for the printed reports so that will also give me some information. And if I see anything of concern I can get a second opinion as my right. But for now... I will work toward enjoying my Christmas Season.
Today, I had my cervical epidural, and I am really hurting tonight. So tomorrow is a day of rest and by Saturday I should be back to happy.
My Christmas gift is not only the diagnosis, it is that I have met a few inspirational women. I humbly thank you. (((Hugs))).
susie
Sue
Posts.Title: Called Back for a Diagnostic Mammo

Posts.Content:
Kat, Bev, Gail... I cannot express enough gratitude for your help. You are amazing women. I find comfort in your words, and help. Whatever this week holds, I know I have some pretty awesome women to listen and give me inspiration. This conversation was really informative. I feel your cyber hugs and positive vibes. I thank you for sharing your experiences with me. I know that if there is something, I will be in good hands here. 
Peace and hugs!!!
I will let you know how it goes for sure. Sue
Sue
Posts.Title: Called Back for a Diagnostic Mammo

Posts.Content:
Tommorrow is the call back day. I am keeping my fingers crossed and hope to score a BINGO.... with B9.
Hugs for all the December call Backs! I will keep you posted. I am going to try to get some sleep.
Sue
Posts.Title: Called Back for a Diagnostic Mammo

Posts.Content:
Tomorrow is the day.  The weekend was busy, so I did not have to do much thinking, but now....work is slow, so I am thinking!  I am getting those pre surgery worries.  I really haven't had much of an appetite today either.  All normal.  I got my cotton bra's today.  So I guess I am ready.  
Sue-Hypothyroid, Abdominal Adhesion Pain, No female parts, no gallbladder. Put a fork in me please!
Posts.Title: Surgical Biopsy Scheduled

Posts.Content:
Thank you to all.. I could not have gotten through the last few days without you. I had discharge this morning, only this time I saw it. It was yellow green. So I guess all this will turn out to be nothing. Fibrocystic breast.... Hmmm. I will find out for sure in a few hours, but that is now what I am expecting. I did see the birads reading on my mammo reports from the previous couple... I have been a consistent Birads 2. So I will let you all know what he says later today. I am thankful for many things this year, and one of them is finding such wonderful ladies as you!!!
Sue-Hypothyroid, Abdominal Adhesion Pain, No female parts, no gallbladder. Put a fork in me please!
Posts.Title: More Confused Now Mammo Then US

Posts.Content:
Happy Thanksgiving all.  I am thankful for you, and all the help and support you have given me in this difficult time.  I had my appointment with my surgeon yesterday and all went well.  He proved to me once again what a wonderful doctor he is.  He has the BEST bedside manor of any doctor I have ever met.   I could hear him go over the reports and films from my mammograms and ultrasounds before he came in.  Then we discussed them, and he said that they were not conclusive, and actually they can miss 10% of cancererous things.  So we proceeded to discuss what was occuring, and my family history, then he went to the physical exam.  When he got to the left breast he was feeling around and then said is this the area?  I said "No"... He said are your sure?  I tilted my head up, and to my surprise it WAS the area!!!  I laughed and said "OOOps, my bad, yes that's it".  
   I honestly thought he was palpating the lymph nodes, with floopy breasts as mine there would be slippage.  He lauged.  He then told me he would treat this one of two ways... 1. Wire guided needle aspiration, or 2. He could just remove it completely.  Then before I could even answer, he added, "With your age, family history, and I can tell how anxious you are, I would prefer to just remove it completely.  
 I didn't even have to ask.  He just knew.  He said that often times women in my position, and even husbands, if he does option one, they are back within 2 months asking for it just to be removed... because as he put it "She/I just keep poking and poking at it".. ROF****!  I asked him if he had secretly been watching me over the last month... He lauged, and added, "As you can tell, I've been doing this awhile".  So he scheduled me immediately for TUESDAY NOV 27th.  I am relieved.  He said he feels it will be benign, but he is more comfortable with the surgical approach because if it is suspicous, he can do more while I am there, then having me come back.  You know I have to say, that even my gyne has proved again why I love her.  She is on vacation this week, but had her staff call me personally on Wednesday to find out what happend...  I am in good hands with both.  I am glad this is a busy long weekend as I won't have to think to much about
 it.  And obviously I will be busy Monday at work to account for the couple of days off I will have next week.  
 
Sue-Hypothyroid, Abdominal Adhesion Pain, No female parts, no gallbladder. Put a fork in me please!
Posts.Title: Surgical Biopsy Scheduled

Posts.Content:
Had the biopsy today. And I am thinking it went well... The surgeon removed what he believes to be a fatty cyst. He believes it will come out benign in pathology. I am sore, but resting well. I am having a hard time now getting comfortable enough to fall asleep. The local is wwearing off, and I am icing and taking my pain meds. I am hoping to get some rest soon. But I wanted to thank everyone for every thing. You all gave me strength during this difficult time. Big big Hugs... Sue
Sue-Hypothyroid, Abdominal Adhesion Pain, No female parts, no gallbladder. Put a fork in me please!
Posts.Title: Surgical Biopsy Scheduled

Posts.Content:
I am so confused.  I don't know what this means.  I went for the diagnostic mamo today.  The tech took pictures, we located the "palpable mass".  When they squeezed for the extra pictures, I leaked. I was surprised and it was dark, it was just a little, and neither of us saw the contents.  She said sometimes that happens because they are squeezing the nipple area so tight.  Anywhoo, she then got a hold of the doctors office to ask for an order for an ultrasound, (since I was already there she said).  So I waited and waited, finally it came through, and off to ultrasound I went.  She squirted the goo, then scanned, and then asked me to find the area.  So I did, it is difficult to find when I lay flat because it sinks into the gobly gook inside my breast, and everything shifts.  She had the radiologist check her measurments and came back in 5 minutes and said I could go, they didn't see anything.  WHAT??????????????  So am I an idiot?  Am I imagining it?  I am so embarrased and confused.
 
 
 
Sue-Hypothyroid, Abdominal Adhesion Pain, No female parts, no gallbladder. Put a fork in me please!
Posts.Title: More Confused Now Mammo Then US

Posts.Content:
Ellen, what a wonderful way of putting it.  That pretty much sums it up.  I will use that one.  Thank you.
 
 
 
 
Sue-Hypothyroid, Abdominal Adhesion Pain, No female parts, no gallbladder. Put a fork in me please!
Posts.Title: Looking for advice

Posts.Content:
Thank you Jen.  It was helpful, and I have been following some of your posts.  I did read something on line somewhere where it was discussed that sometimes palpable masses are difficult to ultrasound if they are deep and difficult to palpate in the laying down position, which mine is.  That sucker likes to go down and hide in that goopy mess when I am laying down.  Unfortunately I will need to wait one more day as my surgeon visit was rescheduled to tomorrow morning due to an emergency surgery today that would have moved my appointment up so far that I would not have had time to get my films, so it would have been pointless.   I got my films, but there was no radiologist report for yesterday, just the reports from previous months and years.  As far as the films, I can't see anything in the mammo from yesterday.  No obvious, "by golly gee will you look at that".  But by golly gee, IT'S STILL THERE IN MY BREAST!!!!! 
 ... So I have to make it one more day... 
Sue-Hypothyroid, Abdominal Adhesion Pain, No female parts, no gallbladder. Put a fork in me please!
Posts.Title: More Confused Now Mammo Then US

Posts.Content:
Hello everyone, I am hoping to get some advice so that I can make good decisions for myself.  I had good results earlier in the year in the heart forum, so I decided to give this a try.  I am 41 close to 42 years old.  My mother was diagnosed with a fast growing malignant breast cancer when she was 40.  By 45 she lost her battle with breast cancer.  Unfortunately when my sister went through a situation where she felt a lump, her surgeon asked her what type of tumor was it that started my mothers journey.  Of course timing is everything and my mothers medical records were destroyed a few months prior to my sisters journey.  And the surgeon was deceased.  So we know nothing. 
   My sister was 28 at that time.  The surgeon she went to, took a invasive conservative approach and removed the lump at biopsy, rather then just sample it and watch.  Turned out to be negative.  He wanted it removed, so that it would not turn into cancer later.  That was 11 years ago.  Here I am today facing something similar.  A lump appeared about
 a month ago followed by a bruise(for no reason), and I have been watching it since I just had my annual mammo in August with no abnormal findings .  Well it did not go away, so I went to my doctor this week.  She confimed yesterday that she feels a mass.  She said based on her experience it feels fibrocystic in nature.  BUT with my family history she wants it evaluated.  So she had the nurse schedule me right then and there for a diagnostic mammo (Monday 11/19), and an appointment with a surgeon (Tuesday 11/20) for second opionion and anything further.  
 
 
Sue-Hypothyroid, Abdominal Adhesion Pain, No female parts, no gallbladder. Put a fork in me please!
